abstract: Buyers in so-called secondary markets that trade private companies including Facebook, Twitter and Zynga are mostly wealthy speculators looking to snag an early piece of the next Apple, Microsoft or Google. Now, the S.E.C. wants to know more.
snippet: Buyers in so-called secondary markets that trade private companies including Facebook, Twitter and Zynga are mostly wealthy speculators looking to snag an early piece of the next Apple, Microsoft or Google. Now, the S.E.C. wants to know more.
lead_paragraph: A red-hot trading market has developed in the shares of the world’s leading social networking companies: Facebook, Twitter, Zynga and LinkedIn. What is unusual is that none of the companies are listed on a public stock exchange. Each is privately held.

headline.main: Stock Trading in Private Companies Draws S.E.C. Scrutiny

abstract: David Yarrow, whose Pegasus fund has had a lackluster year, thinks M.&A. activity will rise, as companies scramble to put their record cash hoard to work.
snippet: David Yarrow, whose Pegasus fund has had a lackluster year, thinks M.&A. activity will rise, as companies scramble to put their record cash hoard to work.
lead_paragraph: A small statistic buried inside the latest investor letter from David Yarrow, manager of London-based hedge fund Pegasus, points to a strong deal-making environment for 2011.

headline.main: Pegasus Chief Predicts Strong Deal-Making in 2011
